What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: Too many - the workload wasn't reasonable
3-7, with greater number of hours during times that assignments were due
Around an assignment deadline it was more
I would estimate I spent at least 40 hours outside of the classroom on this course.
10+ hours per week
2-20 (much more when a project component was due)
10 hours
10 if assignment was due

For weekly readings and homework: 1-2
When sections are due: 12-15
Not useful for people who have work experience in public health practice. Felt like a waste of my money and time.

This class is a ton of work that feels not so worthwhile. I think it's valuable to learn the process of creating an intervention, but all the assigned work and detail work feels like a large burden for a one credit course.

The best part of the course is that there is a very meaningful and significant output of which I am proud. The actual time spent in class varied in its usefulness 

Suggestions:
-Allocate fewer lectures to the "Part 2" section of the course. This part varies so much by group, and more lectures could be added to the "Part 3" section of the course. For those of us who haven't taken Evaluation, this information is new and substantial, and felt rushed. 
-Assign 1-2 Teaching Fellows for the course! There was such a long delay in getting feedback from the professor, perhaps due to a larger than usual class size? Having feedback from a teaching fellow more promptly would make a big difference and ultimately result in higher quality outputs.
I really enjoyed this course. Building an intervention from start to finish is a great learning experience.
I don't have much interest in the subject matter and it was hard to stay engaged. The class would be good for someone very interested in intervention design.

Strengths: 
- Course provided a clear overview and systematic method for developing a health promotion/disease intervention. 
- I really liked the continuity of having three assignments due throughout the semester that would eventually be combined into the final.  Feedback from assignments from both peers and instructor helped a lot with edits for the final manual we submitted.  
- Theatre testing of intervention activities was my favorite portion of the semester -- very active, and also a good way to receive feedback and discuss main concepts behind interventions.  
- I had a really good group, which meant that workload felt very manageable 

Weaknesses: 
- If you are taking this course as a second year, the last two assignments overlapped with thesis deadlines, which did become a little overwhelming.  For future students taking this course, just be sure to keep this in mind when managing time/schedules.
The course was good. I think actually doing the final product was really important, and the skills I learned will carry. The lectures could be improved to make them feel a bit more worthwhile.

It is a very well structured class. I like that we submit each section of the manual separately, because it make sure we space out the work throughout the semester. I also like that we get feedback from Trace on every section we submit. I don't think the participation grade for every clas should be graded on a 0 to 0.5 scale, because it disadvantages people who are shy. There are students who are engaged in class but prefer to have discussions in small groups or one on one.

This class is a ton of work. That said, I think this is one of those classes where the more you put into it, the more you get out of it. I had the extreme fortune to work with an organized, motivated group and we picked an intervention topic that was extremely interesting, which made the course work a lot more enjoyable.
Strengths
-This is a skills-based class. Although I was not super enthusiastic about this class at the beginning, I can see how much I've learned and grown in this class and I have mentioned this class in job interviews for some of the tangible skills I learned (e.g. developing a conceptual model).
-This class is flexible and has lots of room for creativity, which is both fun and challenging. It was pretty exhausting to create all of the intervention activities, but it was also really fun to create new things in a way that we don't get to do in a lot of classes.
Weaknesses
-I didn't find the readings that useful and I stopped doing them after awhile because of how much other work we had to do for the class.
-I think the evaluation module is the weakest part of this class. I think this module would really benefit from having guest lecturers for this component (Marney to talk about the psychometrics, Kathleen to talk about process evaluation).
-I'm not sure the discussions in the class were always super useful, as they seemed very specific to individual group projects. I think this class would be an interesting opportunity to use the "flipped classroom model"--watch a recorded lecture (or a real-time lecture) on Canvas, and then use the class time to troubleshoot and work on class projects.
Great instructor, informative material, engaging discussion and activities

The course was most helpful when we did interactive activities- otherwise the lectures were useful but not always engaging. It was very useful when we applied the lecture materials to our specific projects!
SBS 574 accomplishes a lot in a short amount of time and that is great. However, I wish that we could have seen some part of our intervention projects actually implemented!
I think it was a very informational class - I learned a lot!
Great course with applicable skills for the work force
This course is super practical and helps you develop skills you will use in the future.

The course does a great job of not cutting corners and making sure we are completely able to create an intervention as well as effectively write a manual effectively and describing our motivations, its implementation, and possible evaluation techniques. Sometimes the lectures were difficult to follow for people are are previously familiar with the concepts, but discussion facilitated greater understanding and application. The interactive discussion components and intervention practice opportunities made the class and assignments approachable. I also appreciated the peer review aspect of the assignments in that it gave us an idea of various styles and approaches to the assignment.

Strengths: One of the exceptions at YSPH, a class that is practice based and suited for professional students.
Weakness: Your experience depends on what group you get.
Trace is great.

Trace is very loved in the SBS department. He has a laid back demeanor but was great in answering our questions and helping us to produce our final products. I wish he could have provided more detailed feedback on each of our individual assignments.

Trace is great! He can be a tough grader but he is helpful, funny, and knows his tough. I liked learning about projects he has worked on in the past and lessons learned from them for our interventions.

Trace cares about his students and is overall a good instructor. I appreciate his willingness to meet with students when asked. Grading was inconsistent and seemed overly nitpicky, often without much explanation for why points were deducted. Clearer expectations would strengthen the course.

Strengths: 
- Provided valuable feedback on assignments that helped with the final assignment 
- Was clear about expectations for the assignments 
- Especially for the more quantitative portions of the course (e.g. evaluation, calculating effect sizes), instructor was very good at breaking down more of the complex concepts

Trace was a great professor. He was accommodating and always available to answer any questions. He also gave us very useful feedback our work. Overall, he runs the class in an organized manner, and I have no suggestions for improvements .

I really like Trace. He expects a lot, but he bends over backwards to be flexible and to make things manageable for us. I do wish we got feedback in a more timely fashion. In addition, I think there were some "big personalities" in this class that got a lot of attention just because they made a lot of noise. It would be great if he could use his facilitation skills to draw out some of the quieter people so that we hear from more than just a few people in the class.
Fantastic

Trace is great at providing useful, critical feedback to help define and improve our intervention manuals. It may have been more useful and effective for him to give a lecture once a week and then the other class time leave open for project work and Trace would be able to provide guidance and suggestions during that time.
Trace is great. He has a unique personality and he knows how to teach graduate students.
He was very engaging!
Great instructor, knows the material very well but sometimes not the best at explaining the material to students. However, hes very great at answering questions,  receiving and providing feedback.
Professor Kershaw is great! He lets students work on a project that they are super interested in. He does not make students do busy work, and is always available to help. Awesome professor.

Sometimes Trace was vague in his answers to some of the student questions regarding the more complex issues and models we discussed in class and lectures. His feedback was always helpful to the development of our projects and materials.
Trace is a great teacher. He is engaging, engaged, accessible and available. He is grounded and treats students like adults.

Not at all useful for people with work experience in public health practice. But, it's required for SBS students. You already paid thousands of dollars for this... now you just gotta show up to class and bear it for a few months.
Take it if you must.
This course is a lot of work, but if you have a good group you can create a really meaningful output.
I would only recommend it to those who want to work on designing interventions.

This course will help you to gain valuable skills in developing a health intervention, from conception to implementation.  Would highly recommend taking it.  If you are taking it, I would also recommend being in a group and focusing on a topic that most interests you.  Having a group was really helpful for delegating work, which was very much needed and appreciated while working on the thesis.

I would recommend this class to any student who wants to learn how to build a health intervention from start to finish. The materials we covered in this class are hands on and applicable to the real world. This class is a lot of work, but any student who takes it will gain many practical skills they will use in their future career.

You'll learn a lot from this class, but your enjoyment of this class is directly correlated with your group. My best advice is to pick a group that works in a similar style to you and to pick a topic that you genuinely care about, because you are going to get to know that topic really well. (It helps a lot if you, like me, have already done a lot of work on a certain topic and didn't have to start from square one.) I would recommend this class is you're interested in designing interventions or if you're interested in the more creative side of public health. Just know that it's a lot of work and you need to really commit to that work to enjoy the class.

Yes I would recommend! This course allows you to work with a community organization to develop an intervention manual (from start to finish) which is a very time and labor intensive project, but Trace does a great job of walking you through each step of developing the manual throughout the semester. Very useful, fun, and interesting course!
SBS 574 is a necessary course. Program intervention and evaluation skills are good tools for public health practitioners.
I think it really shows how much work goes into planning an intervention.

You will learn the ins and outs of developing a health promotion intervention from design, to development and evaluation. The course requires a lot of work and background research and can sneak up on you quick. By the type of class to wait until the last minute!
Yes!

The course is a thorough and in-depth description and application of the construction of a public health intervention. I would definitely recommend it to any public health student interested in public health interventions even if not interested in a future in the development and implementation of an intervention. Having an understanding of the theory and process that contributes to a successful intervention as well as the writing abilities to describe ideas around public health and issues of interest.
I definitely would recommend the course for any student who wants to be exposed to programmatic work and implementation.
